comments.commentBody: If this is true ... that Jeter is asking 23 to 24 million per year ... well, let's just hope it's not true.

I'm just waiting for the day sport fans realize the players don't care any more for them than thepolitician equivalents care for their constituents--Rep, Dem, Met, Yank--they just want power and, more importantly, money. To believe otherwise is sad and deluded.

Good luck, NY! Prove me wrong!

Brownie
Please please please pay him . As a lifelong baseball fan and I may add a grudging admirer of Sir Jeter I would love for the Yanks to make another financial gaff. The rest of MLB could use a laugh.

I read something a few months ago that seemed like it made sense (I know it won't make sense in the normal 'corporate' scheme of things): offer him $17 million a year with no contract. Let him play until he can't - or won't - play effectively anymore.
it's more like 20-25 million viewers tuning in when this plays out in an SNL spoof.

The solution is simple: ask the graphic design department faculty at the RIVAL university to have an advanced design class work with a small group of high school students and faculty (acting as clients) to design a totally new high school sports identity (mascot, color, and typography)!

Problem solved. No cost (except for redoing signs, uniforms, etc.). The high school students get to learn about the design process, why creative work by designers is best when it is original and appropriate and they get to work with university students. The university students (chosen as the final design or not) each get a great portfolio concept piece. The rival university puts a feather in its cap. The other university gets a bronx cheer.

Someone should inform both high schools and universities that anything and everything not having to do with providing an education should be off limits to them. Education is not about entertainment and providing spin off products for vainglorious jocks.
American educators should be fighting for America's economic future, for its role as a leader in the arts and sciences, for military supremacy and for national security.
Instead it's a big contest to see can have the best tailgate parties and send the most graduates on to the bizarro world of professional sports where they can be sure to have both body and spirit broken for corporate chump change.
And now it degenerates into, of all things, a whine-athon over some stupid cartoon characters and pretty typefaces surrounded by circles, polygons or just plain splats.
How soon before first graders get hauled away for making crayon likenesses of ( I'd name a school's mascot but don't want to be sued ) to put on their Facebook profile? And remember Facebook now owns the word "face".

I would like to see schools agree, as dignified adults, to some sort of fair-use agreement for names, logos and mascots.

I went to James A Garfield High School and our teams were the Bulldogs. I guarantee that there are hundreds more Garfield High Schools in the nation, and hundreds of Bulldogs; likely my Garfield Bulldogs were not the only ones in the nation, however my school has never been so pretentious as to sue all the others.
That's my question:  suppose the high school can show that its logo clearly pre-dates the college's use?  Hauling aout a few logo-ed school papers from the 1950's, suppose?

really...you're talking about some football schools..enough brainpower in the entire university there to power at least two long multiplication problems... but hey, can they run a fast break...something wrong with our society..
im glad at least one high school fought back!
Penn State might want to look a little closer to home, the mascot of the high school in State College, PA is the "Little Lion" which bears a striking  resemblance to the Nittany Lion.

I think we have found a position within the College system that needs to be cut for cost savings... "Logo Protection Specialist"... should save every school upwards of $150,000 (Salary, Benefits & Pension)  a year plus lawyer fees... another $100,000... please someone tell Washington.

I have lived in Gainesville for 25 years and I am a huge Gator fan. In my humble opinion, going after a high school's logo is rather petty and counterproductive. Whoever is making these decisions is thinking short term. Promoting stronger ties with your friends always pays better dividends than attacking them for mere pennies.
Also, many university design programs already have senior level classes (practicum) that do nothing but design work for non profits, like high schools.

It is about money, but not in the way you may think. Cheap high schools pay amateurs to badly copy other schools' successful brand identities rather than hire professional designers who can create something more original and well-crafted. I'm glad the universities are going after the cheap plagiarists.
Should Green Bay and UGA get in a protracted battle over the G logo? Now, that's something I would pay to see!
Anyone remember the old days when the main reason for college was to get an education (and perhaps to party a bit)?

Sovereign nations in financial trouble...where the trend is not your friend (or anyone else's for that matter). If you want to squeeze the shorts, get the European nations to integrate themselves more and take responsibility to bring the economy of the weaker links in the chain to sustainability. The increase stability in the region will outweight the costs to the stronger nations and the shorts will learn a painful lesson.

steve
http://www.scarsdaleaikido.com

American skeptics pre-euro used to like to point out that although the US has uneven pockets of high and low growth, having all 50 states under a single currency is doable due to (a) labor mobility and (b) the lack of language barriers. The same is not remotely true for Europe.

The proper EU citizen response right now, if this were the US, is to move to Germany to find work. This is obviously not a solution for the vast majority, nor doable politically and socially. To listen meanwhile to self-serving German smugness, whose success is based on the devaluation of the euro with respect to what the DM would be valued at now, is particularly galling. That is, for Germans, participation in the single currency makes German goods underpriced, and those of many EU partners overpriced.

The call now for centralized fiscal policy in the EU, while brilliant in theory, will be an unmitigated disaster that only exacerbates the differences among member states without addressing this key flaw. Weaker states will have virtually no policy levers to address their problems.

Hate to admit it, but the euro is a bust, which bodes ill for the coming years of further turmoil.

Soon to be playing in a theater in America.  Bankrupt USA.  No bailout from Europe.  Budget slashes cause Riots in LA, DC, NY and other major cities.  We have spent ourselves into oblivion just like the Irish and the Italians and the Portugese and the French, et al.  Out comeuppance is just around the corner.  With a moron like Obama spending and borrowing to the hilt it is just a question of time.  If China ever decides to teach us a lesson and stops buying all our debt up, the Great Depression will seem like a picnic.

Bravo to Ms. Merkel who is acting to advance the interests of Germany, which is after all her job.

Every reminder about haircuts drives the interest rates of the PIIGS up. The higher the interest rates they have to pay, the more likely they will move towards balanced budgets and growth oriented policies. If they think they can overshoot the 3% deficit limit by, oh, say, a factor of 10, they need to have another think. Why should Germany fund their deafness?

Alternatively, someone in Germany may say, lets leave the Euro. And maybe they should.
Where is Angela Merkel's Peace Prize?

Pinnochio has more credibility than the brain-dead Europeans.

Last winter Greece said that they did not need a bailout.

A fortnight ago Ireland said that they did not need a bailout.

Now Portugal and Spain are protesting that they too do not need bailouts.

Soon Belgium, Italy, and France will be telling the world that they also are not in need of bailouts.

Maybe they should all try to take economics 101. Their GDP to debt ratios are unsustainable and they cannnot pursue the 'austerity' measures demanded by the clueless idiots in Berlin because that will only reduce aggregate demand to the point where it becomes even more difficult to service their unsustainable debts -- see e.g. where 'austerity' has gotten both Greece and Ireland so far.

So its 'auf wiedersehen' Euro and Euroland.

Couldn't happen to a nicer bunch of pathetic, ignorant, smug, parasites.

comments.userDisplayName: Phil in the mountains of Kyushu
comments.commentBody:
Your colleague Krugman yesterday also lit on this meanness abroad the land.

In his case it was the filthy-rich banking class wrecking Ireland, though 100s of readers’ “comments” of course raised the U.S. parallels.

As I read in K’s first 25 most-recommended “comments,” and last 100 “newest,“ I saw, however, no reference to the Supreme Court’s “Citizens United.” Strange this, as its ruling for the class known by its big piles of money quite flags the reigning meanness of Corporate Land. That five justices could so choose to dehumanize actual people, for the behemoth class of money as equally human, also parallels how U.S. schools model the same classes of dehumanization. It’s by choice – which could be reversed – that the biz and law schools set winning, calculating, tricking above all. Our so-called humanities and social sciences ply their own specializations, siloing the human to their de-natured class.

Why do so many “educators” as well as obviously corporate justices so pump for this class of money, careerism, and depersonalizations?

Will, played by Matt Damon in "Good Will Hunting," shows one answer. Will’s deep flaws in that film show how denial of humanity results in meanest forms of competitiveness. Same fuels regular Corporate Land, standardized-testing-K-12, and departmentalized “higher ed.”

Schools could instead do for Americans what Sean (Robin Williams) does for Will. They could teach how there’s more to life than the machineries of winning, grading, scoring, bilking all for CEO greed, and reducing all to those already schooled to their own most reduced – as you call it today – “class.”
